English[edit]

Proper noun[edit]

Winter

  1. A surname​.
  2. A female given name
  3. A town and village in Wisconsin.

Derived terms[edit]

  • Winter's bark (Drimys winteri)

See also[edit]

  • Winter on Wikipedia.Wikipedia

Anagrams[edit]

  • twiner

Dutch[edit]

Proper noun[edit]

Winter

  1. A surname​.

German[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Middle High German winder, winter, from Old High German wintar, from Proto-Germanic *wintruz. Compare Dutch winter, English winter, Danish vinter.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /ˈvɪntɐ/
  • audio
    		(file)

Noun[edit]

Winter m (genitive Winters, plural Winter)

  1. winter

Declension[edit]

Declension of Winter
singularplural
indef.def.noundef.noun
nominativeeinderWinterdieWinter
genitiveeinesdesWintersderWinter
dativeeinemdemWinterdenWintern
accusativeeinendenWinterdieWinter

Derived terms[edit]

  • winterartig
  • winterlich

Hunsrik[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Middle High German winder, winter, from Old High German wintar, from Proto-Germanic *wintruz.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /ˈvintɐ/

Noun[edit]

Winter m (plural Winter)

  1. winter
    Im Winter werd-s aarich kalt.
    In winter it gets very cold.

See also[edit]

Seasons in Hunsrik · Johreszeide (layout · text)
Frihling (“spring”)Sommer (“summer”)Herrebst (“autumn”)Winter (“winter”)

Further reading[edit]

  • Online Hunsrik Dictionary

Tagalog[edit]

Etymology[edit]

Borrowed from English Winter.

Proper noun[edit]

Winter

  1. A female given name originating from English
